name: peanut production | peanut | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/15115/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of peanuts. The average yield from 2009 - 2012 is 1 t/ha. The data are representative for peanut production in India used for the export market. Mineral NPK fertiliser input is 60-60-0 kg/ha. No organic fertilisers are applied. Total active ingredients (a.i.) applied as pesticides amount to 0.81 kg a.i./ha.;The dataset was modelled within the project 'World Food LCA database (WFLDB)'. The aim of this project was to provide inventories of a broad variety of agricultural products and processes and to cover for each product at least 50% of the global export market. The export share of peanuts produced in India amounts to 30% of the global export (tonnage exported in 2010). The production system regarded in this dataset aimed at representing peanuts produced in India for the export market.;PEF-Quality: data quality rating (DQR) = 1.7 (i.e. very good). This dataset refers to an average situation; for specific situations exchanges might differ substantially due to site specific parameters

This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.

This activity ends with the harvest of peanuts at farm gate. The dataset includes all machine operations, corresponding infrastructure, fuel use and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, pesticide application, harvesting, and on-farm transport. Further, direct field emissions and land use change are included. Heavy metal uptake by the crop is considered. The inputs of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides as well as packaging of fertilisers and pesticides are considered.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/011:Growing of non-perennial crops/0111:Growing of cereals (except rice), leguminous crops and oil seeds

processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: If used, extrapolations are documented on the flow level.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Principles of the sampling procedure is described in the WFLDB Methodological Guidelines for the Life Cycle Inventory of Agricultural Products version 3.0, available at: (Report section: https://v30.ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/File/Reports). Data sources: Data were categorised from level 0 (L0) to level (L4) as follows: L0 = estimate, proxy; L1 = statistical data (e.g. FAOSTAT); L2 = L1 adapted to crop and country; L3 = literature data or L1 resp. L2 data approved by experts; medium detailing (i.e. kg of total N-fertiliser); L4 = L3 data of high detailing (i.e. portion N-fertiliser types).In this dataset data were obtained for yield: L3; Fertilisers: L4; Pesticides: L4; Machinery: L2/L4; Irrigation: L3. For information regarding the calculation of individual exchanges see supporting documentation WFLDB-Documentation.pdf.

The exchange has been updated from 'urea, as N' into 'urea' and therefore its amount has been scaled (multiplied) from 0.03 kg by 2.1438 kg of 'urea' per kg of 'urea, as N'. Original comment of the exchange is: Calculated based on literature values or expert estimation: The total amount of nutrient (Personal written communication, Binaya Kumar Parida., Yara, 2015) multiplied by the share of fertiliser type (Personal written communication, Binaya Kumar Parida., Yara, 2015). exchanges.description: Calculated value - Freiermuth (2006). See 'WFLDB-Guidelines.pdf', available at https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/File/Reports. This emission might be overestimated in case of basic soils.

Total amount of active substance/s of fertilisers needed for the production of 'peanut' is calculated to be circa 1.20E-01 kg. Fertiliser/s used in this dataset is/are: 'nitrogen fertiliser, as N', 'phosphate fertiliser, as P2O5', 'urea, as N'. The total amount of active substance/s is doubled in order to account for the packaging of the dilluted product of fertiliser/s that is/are applied. Therefore, 2.40E-01 kg of packaging for fertilisers is justified with this exchange.
